content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Elizabeth Smith: Well, I was born in São Paulo, Brazil, but I moved to the United States when I was just a baby. My family settled in Charleston, South Carolina, and I grew up there. My childhood wasn't easy—my family wasn't well off, and I remember having to work part-time jobs from a young age to help out. My mother was a teacher, and she always encouraged me to value education, even though my father only had a high school diploma. I left home before I turned 16 to attend a boarding school in the state, which was a big change for me. I missed my family a lot, but I knew it was an opportunity to get a better future. I earned a bachelor's degree in business administration, and I've been working full-time ever since. I married my husband, James, a few years ago, and we're trying to build a stable life together. I'm proud of where I've come from, and I still speak Portuguese at home with my parents when they visit. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I've always tried to stay positive and focused on the future.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Elizabeth Smith: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads. After I graduated from high school, I had two main options: stay in Charleston and work at the local store where my mother's sister worked, or take a scholarship to a boarding school in North Carolina. The scholarship was a huge opportunity, but leaving my family was terrifying. I remember sitting at the kitchen table with my parents, my mother crying and my father just nodding silently. I chose the boarding school, and that decision changed everything. It was hard—adjusting to a new environment, making friends, and dealing with homesickness. But I met teachers who believed in me, and I started to see myself as someone who could achieve more than I ever thought possible. That experience taught me resilience and the value of education. It also shaped my perspective on life—now I believe that sometimes the hardest choices are the ones that lead to the most growth.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Elizabeth Smith: I think, in that moment, it was a conscious choice, but one that felt almost inevitable. I knew staying in Charleston would mean a life of routine, working at the store, maybe never leaving the city. I wanted more for myself, even if I didn't know exactly what that more looked like. I remember telling my mother that I didn't want to be stuck in the same place my father was—working a job that didn't challenge me, not really growing. I think I was afraid of regret more than anything else. And so, I made the choice to take the scholarship, even though it scared me to death. Looking back, I don't think I could have made a different decision and still been the same person I am today.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Elizabeth Smith: Absolutely. My mother was the one who really pushed me to consider the scholarship. She had always believed in education, even though she wasn't able to pursue it herself. She worked multiple jobs to support my father and me, and she never complained. When I was struggling with the decision, she sat me down and said, 'If you don't take this chance, you'll always wonder what could have been.' That stayed with me. I also remember the principal from the boarding school reaching out to my mother after I applied, telling her that I had potential and that the school wanted to give me a shot. I think it was a combination of people—my mother's belief in me, the school's willingness to take a chance on a student from a different background, and my own fear of regret—that helped me take that step. Without them, I don't know if I would have had the courage to leave everything I knew behind.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Elizabeth Smith: Yes, I'm married to James, who works in IT. We met a few years ago through a mutual friend, and we've been together ever since. He's been a great support through everything—my education, my career, and even my fears of not being good enough. We don't have children yet, but we're hoping to start a family in the next few years. James is very involved in our community, and I admire how he balances his work with helping others. Our relationship is built on mutual respect and shared goals. I think he's one of the reasons I've been able to stay grounded and focused on what really matters. We both value education and hard work, and I feel lucky to have someone who believes in me as much as I believe in him.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how far I've come and how much my choices have shaped who I am today. Reflecting on my childhood, the struggles, and the pivotal decision to leave home for the boarding school, I realize how much courage it took to take that step. My mother's unwavering belief in me and the support I received from the school were crucial in helping me grow. Now, as I look at my life with James, I feel grateful for the path I chose—even though it wasn't easy. These questions made me appreciate how every challenge and opportunity has led me to where I am today, and I'm proud of the person I've become.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Elizabeth Smith: My immediate family includes my parents, who still live in São Paulo, and my younger sister, Ana. We stay in touch through phone calls and video chats, even though it's not the same as being together. My parents have always been proud of me, even though they didn't have the same opportunities growing up. My father, though he only finished high school, has always supported my education and encouraged me to keep learning. My mother, on the other hand, is the one who truly shaped my values—she taught me the importance of perseverance, kindness, and always striving for more. My sister, Ana, is a few years younger than me, and while we didn't grow up together because I left for boarding school, we've always had a close bond. She's studying to become a nurse, and I'm so proud of her. I hope to visit them more often now that my life is more stable, and I know they're always cheering me on from afar.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Elizabeth Smith: Yes, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met at the boarding school. We were in the same class, and we bonded over our shared struggles and dreams. She's now a social worker in Charleston, and she's always been there for me—whether it was during my studies or when I was figuring out my career path. She's one of the few people who really understood what it was like to come from a different background and still want to make something of yourself. Then there's Marcus, who I met later in my career. He works in marketing, and we've been friends for almost a decade. He's the kind of person who always knows how to make me laugh, even on my worst days. I think having friends like Sarah and Marcus has been crucial to my growth. They remind me that I'm not alone, and that there are people who genuinely care about me and my journey.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Elizabeth Smith: I live in a quiet neighborhood in Charleston, just a few blocks away from the downtown area. It's a mix of older homes and newer developments, and there's a real sense of community here. I love that there are local shops, cafes, and parks nearby—places where you can really get to know your neighbors. My house is a small two-story home with a small backyard where James and I have started a little garden. It's not much, but it's ours, and it feels like a symbol of the life we're building together. I also enjoy the proximity to the library and community center, which are both great resources for learning and connecting with others. Charleston has a rich history, and I find myself walking through the historic district often, just taking in the architecture and the stories that the city holds. It's a place that feels both familiar and full of possibility, and I'm grateful to call it home now.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Elizabeth Smith: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. Charleston has its share of challenges, like anywhere else, but the neighborhood I live in is tight-knit and watchful. People know each other, and there's a sense of mutual respect. I've never had any real issues with crime or safety, which is something I'm grateful for. It helps that James and I both feel comfortable in our surroundings, and we've made friends with a few of our neighbors. I think safety is also about the environment you create for yourself—being part of a community where people look out for one another makes a big difference. I don't worry about walking home at night or leaving the door unlocked when I'm out. It's one of the things that makes this place feel like a real home to me.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Elizabeth Smith: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the sense of community and the opportunities that Charleston offers. There's always something happening—local festivals, art shows, and even charity events that bring people together. It's a city that feels alive, and I enjoy being part of that energy. But it's not without its challenges. The cost of living here can be tough, especially with the rent and utilities. We've had to be careful with our budget, and sometimes it feels like we're always balancing between saving and enjoying what the city has to offer. I also miss the slower pace of life in some ways—back in Brazil, life wasn't as fast-paced, and there was more time for family. But I think I've come to appreciate the rhythm of life here. It's a place that pushes you to grow, to keep learning, and to never stop striving. I wouldn't trade it for anything, even with the struggles.

Going through the questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety made me reflect on how much my current life is shaped by the people and places around me. Talking about James and our future together reminded me of how important it is to have a partner who supports your dreams and shares your values. Thinking about my parents and sister made me realize how much I owe them for their love and encouragement, even from afar. And when I described my neighborhood in Charleston, I felt a deep sense of gratitude for the community we've built here. It's not perfect, but it's real, and it's ours. The questions also made me think about how safety and belonging are more than just physical things—they're about feeling connected, supported, and at home in both your environment and your relationships.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Elizabeth Smith: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though there's always some flexibility depending on work or family plans. I start my week early—usually around 6:30 a.m.—with a quick workout at the local gym, which is just a few blocks away. James usually wakes up later, so I make him breakfast while I get ready for work. I work full-time in marketing, so my days are pretty busy. Mondays and Fridays tend to be the busiest, with meetings and deadlines, while Wednesdays are usually lighter, which I use to catch up on reading or plan our week. On weekends, we try to spend time together—whether it's a walk in the park, a visit to a local café, or just relaxing at home. I also make it a point to call my parents on Sundays, which is something I've always valued. Even though life here is fast-paced, I find comfort in the routine and the little moments that make it feel like home.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Elizabeth Smith: I work full-time as a marketing coordinator for a small nonprofit organization that focuses on educational outreach in underserved communities. My job is pretty demanding, but I love the impact it has—knowing that my work helps provide resources and opportunities to kids who might not have them otherwise. I usually start my workday around 8:30 a.m., and I'm typically done by 5:00 p.m., though I often stay a little later on busy days to wrap up projects or meet with colleagues. I've been in this role for about three years now, and it's been a great fit for me both professionally and personally. It aligns with my values of education and community support, and I feel like I'm making a real difference, even in small ways. It's not always easy—there are days when the budget is tight or the deadlines are overwhelming—but I remind myself why I started this path in the first place, and that keeps me going.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Elizabeth Smith: Outside of work, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. Every evening after work, I try to spend some quiet time with a book or journaling—something that helps me process the day and reflect on my goals. I also take care of our small garden on the weekends, which has become a kind of therapy for me. It's amazing how planting seeds and watching them grow mirrors the way I see my own life—sometimes slow, sometimes unpredictable, but always worth the effort. I also volunteer a few hours each month at the community center, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's a way to give back, especially since I know how much support I received when I was younger. And, of course, I make sure to set aside time for James—whether it's cooking together, going for a run, or just talking about our future. Life is busy, but these little routines help me stay balanced and connected to what truly matters.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Elizabeth Smith: Well, recently, I've started waking up a bit earlier than usual to get in a little more exercise before work. I've been trying to be more consistent with my fitness routine, and it's been helping me feel more energized throughout the day. I also started taking evening walks with James after dinner, which has been a nice way to unwind and talk about our goals for the future. Another change is that I've been spending more time planning our upcoming trip to visit my family in Brazil. It's something we've been looking forward to for a while, and I've been researching flights and accommodations to make sure everything goes smoothly. It's been a bit of a learning curve, but I'm excited to see them again and show them the life we're building here. These small changes have been a good reminder to slow down and appreciate the little things, even in the midst of a busy life.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Elizabeth Smith: Well, we don't have children yet, but we've been talking a lot about what our lives would look like once we do. I imagine that a typical weekday during the school year would start early for them—maybe around 7:00 a.m., with a healthy breakfast and a bit of time to get ready. I hope to instill in them the same love of learning that my mother gave me, so I envision them heading off to school with a backpack full of books and a sense of curiosity. After school, I'd love for them to have a variety of activities—maybe something creative like art or music, and something physical like sports or dance. I think it's important for kids to explore different interests and find what makes them happy. James and I would both be involved in their lives, helping with homework, attending school events, and making sure they feel supported. I know it's still a ways off, but I can already see the kind of family we want to build—one filled with love, learning, and laughter.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life is shaped by the people and places around me. Talking about my family, especially James, reminded me of how important it is to have a partner who supports your dreams and shares your values. Thinking about my parents and sister made me realize how much I owe them for their love and encouragement, even from afar. When I described my neighborhood in Charleston, I felt a deep sense of gratitude for the community we've built here. It's not perfect, but it's real, and it's ours. The questions also made me think about how safety and belonging are more than just physical things—they're about feeling connected, supported, and at home in both your environment and your relationships. Reflecting on my job and daily routines reminded me of the balance I strive for between work, family, and personal growth. I'm grateful for the structure and the small moments that make life feel meaningful, even when it's busy and challenging.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Elizabeth Smith: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs over the years. I've always been pretty active, even as a child—helping out with chores, walking to school, and later, keeping up with the demands of boarding school. I do have a few things I watch out for, like my blood pressure, which runs a bit on the higher side in my family. I make sure to check in with my doctor regularly and keep track of it. I also have a history of mild anxiety, especially during stressful times in my life, like when I was deciding to leave home for the boarding school or when I was starting my career. Over the years, I've learned to manage it through exercise, journaling, and talking to James or my friends when I need to. I try to eat well, mostly plant-based with some lean proteins, and I take supplements like magnesium and omega-3s to support my mental and physical health. I know I'm not perfect about it—there are days when I skip a workout or eat something less healthy—but I'm working on it. Overall, I feel lucky that I haven't had any major health issues, and I'm grateful for the body that's carried me through all my life's challenges so far.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Elizabeth Smith: I think what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine and knowing the importance of taking care of myself. When I was younger, I didn't always prioritize it, but after going through some tough times, I realized that my health is the foundation of everything else. What makes it harder, though, is the constant busyness of life—work, responsibilities, and trying to balance everything with James. There are days when I get caught up in the chaos and forget to eat properly or take a break. But I've learned that even small things, like taking a walk during lunch or making time for a quick stretch, can make a big difference. I also find that having a support system helps—James reminds me to slow down when I'm rushing, and my friends often encourage me to take care of myself. It's not always easy, but I keep coming back to the same truth: if I don't take care of my health, I can't take care of the life I want to build.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Elizabeth Smith: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some persistent lower back pain, which I think came from a combination of sitting for long hours at work and not always taking the time to stretch properly. I didn't think much of it at first, but it started to affect my sleep and my ability to enjoy my morning workouts. I finally made an appointment with a physical therapist, and through a combination of exercises and posture adjustments, I've been able to manage the pain much better. It was a reminder that even small things can have a big impact on your quality of life, and that taking care of your body is an ongoing process. I also started seeing a nutritionist a few months ago to help me fine-tune my diet, which has been really helpful in keeping my energy levels steady and my anxiety in check. It's been a learning experience, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the tools I now have to stay healthy moving forward.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Elizabeth Smith: Honestly, the back pain did make things a bit more challenging, especially with my job requiring long hours at a desk. There were days when I had to take it easy or adjust my schedule to avoid pushing through the pain. But I didn't let it stop me from working or caring for James, even though it did take some mental and physical adjustments. It made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signs. I think if I had ignored it longer, it could have affected more than just my work—it could have impacted my ability to be present for the people I care about. So, while it was a setback, it also became a turning point for me to prioritize my health more seriously. I've learned that taking care of myself isn't just about being strong—it's about being there for the life I want to build with James and for the future we're planning.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Elizabeth Smith: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I've felt more grounded and hopeful than ever, while other days I've been overwhelmed by the weight of responsibilities. I think the biggest shift has been in how I view my own resilience. After dealing with the back pain and making changes to my health, I've started to see myself as someone who can adapt and grow through challenges. I've also felt a deeper sense of gratitude for the people in my life—James, my friends, and even my parents, who continue to support me from afar. I've been working on setting clearer boundaries between work and personal time, which has helped me feel more balanced. There were moments when I felt uncertain about the future, especially with the plans for our family, but I've learned to trust the process. I think, more than anything, I've felt a sense of purpose in what I do—knowing that my work helps others, even in small ways, gives me a sense of meaning that I didn't always have before. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm exactly where I need to be, growing and learning every day.

Going through the interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines shape the way I experience life. Talking about my recent changes, like waking up earlier for exercise and taking evening walks with James, reminded me of how small adjustments can lead to bigger improvements in well-being. Thinking about my health—my back pain, my anxiety, and the steps I've taken to manage them—made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signals it sends. It also made me appreciate the support I have from James and my friends, who help keep me grounded when life gets overwhelming. Reflecting on my health struggles and the progress I've made showed me that growth isn't always about big, dramatic changes—it can also be about showing up every day, even when it's hard, and taking care of myself in the little ways that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Elizabeth Smith: I think I've struggled with anxiety at different points in my life, especially during times of major change or uncertainty. When I was deciding to leave home for the boarding school, or when I was starting my career, I felt that constant pressure to prove myself, to not let my family down, and to make the most of the opportunities I had. There were days when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. Over time, I've learned to recognize the signs—when my thoughts start racing, when I can't sleep, or when I feel like I'm stuck in a loop of worry. I've started talking to a therapist a few months ago, which has been really helpful. It's not that I'm completely free of anxiety now, but I feel more equipped to handle it. I've also found that mindfulness practices, like deep breathing or meditation, help me stay centered. I think the key for me has been accepting that anxiety is a part of life, but it doesn't have to control it. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the tools I now have to manage it and live a more peaceful life.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Elizabeth Smith: For my family, it's been a mix of pride, support, and occasional worry, especially from my parents. They've always been proud of me, but I can tell they worry about the distance and the challenges I face here. My mother, in particular, has been very open about her concerns, especially when I was dealing with the back pain and the stress of work. She calls me almost every week, and even though we speak in Portuguese most of the time, she always ends the call with a reminder to take care of myself. My father is more reserved, but I know he's proud of the life I've built and the opportunities I've had. As for my sister, Ana, she's been my biggest cheerleader. She's always encouraging me to keep going, to keep pushing forward, and she's even started helping me with some of my Portuguese lessons for when we visit. I think the distance has made us closer in some ways, even though it's not the same as being together. They've always believed in me, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Elizabeth Smith: For me, religion has always been a quiet presence in my life—something that shapes my values more than it dictates my daily actions. I was raised Protestant, just like my parents, and I still find comfort in the rituals and teachings of the faith. I don't go to church regularly, but I do believe in the importance of community, kindness, and living with integrity—values that are deeply rooted in my religion. My mother, in particular, has always emphasized the importance of faith as a source of strength, especially during difficult times. I think it's helped me through moments of doubt or fear, like when I was leaving home for the boarding school or when I was struggling with anxiety. I don't see religion as something that needs to be loud or outwardly expressed, but rather as a quiet foundation that guides me. It's not the center of my life, but it's something I'm grateful for, and I hope to pass those values on to my future children if we have any.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Elizabeth Smith: I use social media more for staying in touch with family and friends than for keeping up with the wider world. I have a Facebook account where I share updates about my life, especially photos of our garden or our weekend walks with James. I also use it to stay connected with my parents and sister, especially since we don't see each other often. My mother loves seeing pictures of my work or our little home, and she always comments on how proud she is of me. I don't use Instagram as much, but I do follow a few local Charleston pages for events and community news. I think social media has its place, but I try not to get caught up in the constant stream of information or comparisons. It's more about staying connected to the people I care about rather than trying to keep up with trends or what's happening elsewhere. I also use it to share some of my thoughts on education and community work, which is something I'm passionate about. It's not a big part of my life, but it helps me feel closer to the people who matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Elizabeth Smith: Honestly, I haven't used social media as a source of emotional or financial support during tough times, though I can see how it might help others. For me, it's more about staying connected with the people I care about rather than seeking support online. That said, I have found comfort in sharing certain moments with my close friends—like when I was dealing with the back pain or feeling overwhelmed with work. Sometimes, just posting a photo of my garden or a walk with James and getting a message from Sarah or Marcus saying, 'You're doing great,' has been enough to lift my spirits. I think it's more about the sense of connection than anything else. I don't think I'd ever turn to social media for financial help, but I do believe in the power of community, whether online or in person. It's just that for me, the real support has always come from the people I know and love, not from the virtual world.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and emotional well-being are deeply intertwined with the choices I make every day. Talking about my back pain reminded me of how even small changes—like adjusting my posture or taking time to stretch—can have a big impact on my quality of life. It also made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signals it sends. Reflecting on my anxiety and the ways I've learned to manage it—through therapy, mindfulness, and support from James and my friends—helped me see how far I've come. I used to feel like I had to carry everything on my own, but now I understand that asking for help is a strength, not a weakness. These conversations also made me think about how my mental health affects not just me, but the people I love. I want to be present for James, for my family, and for the future we're building together, and that starts with taking care of myself. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that growth happens in small, consistent steps—like showing up for my workouts, talking to my therapist, or simply taking a deep breath when life feels overwhelming. I'm grateful for the progress I've made and for the tools I now have to keep moving forward, even when the path isn't always clear.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Elizabeth Smith: In the past few months, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually decreased a bit, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've been more intentional about how I manage my time and energy. I've started setting clearer boundaries between work and personal life, which has helped me feel more in control. I also try to practice mindfulness more often—whether it's through deep breathing exercises or simply taking a few minutes to be present in the moment. When I feel overwhelmed, I've learned to reach out to James or my friends, and that has made a world of difference. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see that asking for support is a strength, not a weakness. I'm also more aware of my emotional triggers now, and I try to address them before they spiral out of control. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm developing healthier coping strategies that are helping me navigate life with more grace and resilience.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Elizabeth Smith: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent and utilities, which take up a significant chunk of our budget. We live in a two-story home that's not too big, but it's in a good neighborhood, and the rent is still pretty steep for Charleston. Then there's the cost of groceries, especially since I try to eat healthy and support local farmers when I can. I also have a car payment, insurance, and some savings set aside for emergencies. On top of that, I contribute to a small amount for my parents' care back in Brazil, just to help them with everyday things. James and I are pretty careful with our money—we track every dollar and try to avoid unnecessary spending. It's not always easy, especially with the cost of living here, but we've learned to prioritize what really matters. I think the most important thing is that we're not in debt, and we're working toward a future where we can afford more stability, like buying a home or starting a family. It's a balancing act, but I feel good about the way we're managing it.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Elizabeth Smith: Last month, our household spent around $3,200, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend about $2,800 to $3,500 depending on the month, with rent being the largest single expense—around $1,400. Then there's utilities, which average about $250, and groceries, which we keep around $600 to $700. I also set aside about $300 for car payments and insurance, and another $200 for savings. We also contribute about $100 a month to help my parents with expenses back in Brazil, which is something we've always felt was important. Occasionally, we spend a bit more on things like dining out or weekend activities, but we're careful not to go overboard. Overall, it's a tight budget, but we've learned to live within our means and prioritize what truly matters—like our health, our home, and our future together.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Elizabeth Smith: We rent our home. It's a two-story house in a quiet neighborhood just a few blocks from downtown. Renting has been the practical choice for us right now, especially since we're still building our savings and planning for the future. We've been in this house for about two years, and I really like the sense of community here. Our landlord is very understanding, and it's been a good fit for our lifestyle. I think we'll probably look into buying a home in the next few years, but for now, renting gives us the flexibility we need as we work toward that goal.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Elizabeth Smith: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and holidays. In the winter months, our utility bills—particularly heating—go up significantly. We've had to be more mindful of turning down the thermostat and using space heaters strategically to keep costs down. Then, during the summer, our electricity bill spikes because of air conditioning, and we've started using fans more and closing windows during the day to keep the house cooler. Holidays like Christmas and Thanksgiving bring a few extra expenses, like decorations, meals, and sometimes gifts for my parents back in Brazil. We also noticed a slight increase in our grocery bills during the school year when we started buying more snacks and ingredients for weekend meals. On the flip side, during the summer, we tend to spend more on dining out or going to local events, which can add up. Overall, it's been a balancing act, but we've gotten better at anticipating these changes and adjusting our budget accordingly. It's not always perfect, but it's helped us stay on track and not get caught off guard.

Going through the interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and the tools I use to stay connected with them influence my emotional well-being. Talking about my parents and sister reminded me of how their love and support have been a constant in my life, even from afar. It also made me realize how much I value the small moments of connection—like seeing their faces on video calls or receiving their words of encouragement. Reflecting on my use of social media showed me how it's not about the platforms themselves, but how I choose to use them. For me, it's about staying close to the people I care about, not about keeping up with trends or comparisons. It also made me think about how my mental health is tied to the relationships I nurture and the boundaries I set. I'm grateful for the support I receive from my family and friends, and I'm learning to use the tools I have—whether in person or online—to stay grounded and connected in a world that can sometimes feel overwhelming.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Elizabeth Smith: I do save, though it's something I've had to be really intentional about. We have a savings account that we contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. It's not always easy, especially with the way our budget fluctuates, but I've learned that even $100 a month adds up over time. I also try to set aside money for specific goals—like the trip to Brazil or eventually buying a home. I think the biggest challenge has been resisting the urge to spend on things that don't truly matter, like impulse purchases or unnecessary subscriptions. James and I have started using a budgeting app to track our expenses and savings, which has been really helpful. It's not about being rich, but about having a sense of security and being able to plan for the future. I know that saving isn't always fun, but it's something I've come to value deeply, especially knowing how much my parents sacrificed to give me the opportunities they never had.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Elizabeth Smith: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals. We have an emergency fund that we're slowly building, which is something I've always felt was important, especially given my parents' experiences. They never had that safety net, and I want to make sure that James and I aren't caught off guard by unexpected expenses. At the same time, I've been saving specifically for our trip to Brazil—something we've been dreaming about for a while. It's not just about the travel itself, but about being able to show my parents and sister the life we're building here. I also started saving for a down payment on a home, even though it feels like a distant goal right now. It's been a balancing act, but I've learned that saving doesn't have to be all or nothing—it's about making small, consistent choices that add up over time. I think the most important thing is that we're not just saving for the future, but for the kind of future we want to create together.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Smith: I work as a marketing coordinator for a small nonprofit organization focused on educational outreach in underserved communities. My role involves developing and implementing marketing strategies to raise awareness about the programs we offer, such as after-school tutoring, mentorship initiatives, and scholarship opportunities for students who might not otherwise have access to them. One of the most important parts of my job is working closely with local schools and community leaders to understand their needs and tailor our messaging to be both effective and culturally sensitive. I also manage our social media presence, create content for our website, and collaborate with volunteers and donors to ensure our message reaches as many people as possible. What I love most about this work is seeing the impact it has—whether it's a student who gets into a better school because of our support or a parent who feels more empowered to advocate for their child's education. It's not always easy, especially with limited resources, but knowing that my efforts contribute to real change makes it all worth it.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Elizabeth Smith: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch a bit longer depending on deadlines or projects. My job is pretty demanding, especially during the school year when we're launching new initiatives or preparing for fundraising events. I typically start my workday around 8:30 a.m. and finish by 5:00 p.m., but I often stay a little later on Mondays and Fridays to wrap up meetings or finalize campaign materials. I also spend a few hours each week on weekends catching up on emails or planning upcoming events. It's not always easy to keep work and personal life separate, but I've learned to set boundaries—like not checking work emails after 8:00 p.m. or making sure I take a full lunch break. I think the most important part of my job is knowing that what I do helps kids in underserved communities get the resources they need. Even on the busiest days, I remind myself why I chose this path, and that keeps me motivated.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Elizabeth Smith: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on one role at a time, especially since I wanted to give my full attention to whatever I was doing. When I was in college, I worked part-time at a bookstore to help with expenses, but that was more of a side job while I was studying. After I graduated and started my career in marketing, I committed to that path fully. I think having multiple jobs would have stretched me too thin, especially with the demands of my work and the need to maintain a balance with my personal life. James has always supported me in that—encouraging me to focus on what matters most and not take on more than I can handle. I do take on some freelance projects occasionally, like helping local nonprofits with their social media or writing content for community events, but those are more flexible and don't interfere with my main job. It's important to me to have a clear focus and to be present for the work I do, even if it means saying no to other opportunities.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how far I've come in learning to prioritize my mental health—setting boundaries, practicing mindfulness, and reaching out for support when I need it. It also made me realize how important it is to take care of myself so I can be present for the people I love, like James and my family. Reflecting on our monthly budget and how we manage our expenses showed me how much we've grown in being responsible with our money, even though it's not always easy. I'm proud of the way we've built a life that's stable and meaningful, and I feel grateful for the tools we've developed to handle both the emotional and financial challenges that come with it. It's not perfect, but it's real, and it's ours.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Elizabeth Smith: In total, our household made around $5,200 in the past month. I earn a salary as a marketing coordinator, and James has a steady income from his work in IT. We both contribute to the household, which helps us manage our expenses more effectively. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our rent, utilities, groceries, and other necessities while still allowing us to save a little each month. I think the most important thing is that we're both working toward the same goals—building a stable life, planning for the future, and making sure we can provide for each other and, eventually, for any children we may have. It's not always easy, but I feel grateful for the work we both do and the life we're creating together.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Elizabeth Smith: I've been at my current job for about three years now, and it's been a really rewarding experience. The nonprofit I work for is small, which means I get to wear a lot of different hats—sometimes I'm managing social media, other times I'm organizing events or working directly with community leaders. The benefits of the job are pretty standard: health insurance, dental and vision coverage, and a decent amount of paid time off. We get about two weeks of vacation each year, plus sick days and personal days. I also appreciate the flexibility they offer, especially with the option to work from home a few days a week. It's not the kind of job that pays a lot, but it's meaningful, and I feel like I'm making a real difference in the lives of others. The team is supportive, and I've learned a lot from my colleagues. I think what matters most to me is that I can do work I believe in, and that I'm part of something bigger than myself.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Elizabeth Smith: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a great rapport with my manager, who's been very supportive of me since I started. She's someone who believes in the mission of the organization and encourages her team to do the same. She's always open to feedback and willing to help me grow in my role, whether it's through new projects or professional development opportunities. As for my coworkers, we get along really well. We're a small team, so we're all pretty close, and we often collaborate on different initiatives. There's a real sense of camaraderie here—everyone is passionate about what we do, and that makes the work environment feel more like a community than just a job. I think the fact that we're all working toward a common goal, helping kids in underserved communities, really strengthens our relationships. It's not always easy, especially with limited resources and tight deadlines, but I feel lucky to be part of a team that's dedicated, kind, and always willing to lend a hand when needed.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Elizabeth Smith: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there are some flexibilities depending on the projects we're working on. I usually start at 8:30 a.m. and finish by 5:00 p.m., but I often stay a little later on Mondays and Fridays to wrap up meetings or finalize campaign materials. The organization is pretty understanding about the need for flexibility, especially when we're launching new initiatives or preparing for events. I also have the option to work from home a couple of days a week, which has been a huge help in balancing my personal life with my professional responsibilities. That said, there are times when things get hectic, and I might have to adjust my hours or work late, but overall, I feel like I have a good balance. I think the predictability of the schedule helps me plan better, and the flexibility is something I really appreciate, especially with how much I value time with James and our growing family.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Elizabeth Smith: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation, though I know there's always room for growth. We're not wealthy by any means, but we're not struggling either. It's a balance—sometimes it feels like we're just scraping by, especially with the rising cost of living in Charleston, but other times, I look at what we've built together and feel proud. James and I both work hard, and we've learned to be intentional with our money, which gives me a sense of control. I know that financial security isn't just about having a lot—it's about knowing that we can handle unexpected things, like a medical bill or a car repair, without falling into debt. I also feel good about the fact that we're saving for the future, whether it's for a home, a family, or just to have some peace of mind. There are days when I worry about what the future holds, especially with the uncertainty of the economy, but I try to focus on what we can control. I think, more than anything, I feel grateful that we're not in a position where we're fighting to make ends meet. We're building something, and that gives me hope.

I'm proud of the way we've built a life that's stable and meaningful, and I feel grateful for the tools we've developed to handle both the financial and emotional challenges that come with it. It's not perfect, but it's real, and it's ours.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Elizabeth Smith: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their situations were quite different. My mother worked as a teacher, which was her passion, and she always found ways to make ends meet, even when times were tough. She worked full-time at a local school, and sometimes she took on extra jobs, like tutoring or grading papers for other teachers, just to help support the family. She never complained, even when she was exhausted. My father, on the other hand, worked in construction, which was a more physically demanding job. He didn't have the same level of education, but he was always proud of the work he did. He worked long hours, often coming home tired, but he always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. Looking back, I realize how much sacrifice they made for me and my sister. It wasn't easy for them, especially with the financial struggles we faced, but they never let that stop them from believing in the importance of education and hard work. I think that's why I value both so much today—it's because they showed me what it meant to persevere, even when the path wasn't clear.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Smith: My mother was a teacher at a local public school in Charleston, and her most important activities were planning her lessons, grading papers, and working closely with students and their parents to ensure they were on track academically. She had a deep passion for education and often stayed late after school to help students who were struggling. She also took on extra work, like tutoring or grading for other teachers, to help support our family during tougher times. My father worked in construction, managing small projects and overseeing crews. His most important duties were ensuring the work was done safely and on time, and he took pride in the quality of his work. He worked long hours, often coming home tired, but he always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. Looking back, I realize how much sacrifice they made for me and my sister. It wasn't easy for them, especially with the financial struggles we faced, but they never let that stop them from believing in the importance of education and hard work. I think that's why I value both so much today—it's because they showed me what it meant to persevere, even when the path wasn't clear.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Elizabeth Smith: My mother worked for the Charleston Public School District, which is a government-run organization that provides education to students across the city. She taught middle school English, and her job involved not only planning and delivering lessons but also getting to know her students on a personal level. She believed that education was more than just textbooks and tests—it was about helping kids find their voice and believe in themselves. My father worked for a small construction company that specialized in residential projects. He was a foreman, which meant he was responsible for overseeing the day-to-day operations of the crew, making sure everything was done safely and on schedule. He didn't earn a lot, but he took pride in his work and always made sure that the homes he helped build were strong and well-made. Looking back, I realize how much they both gave to make sure my sister and I had the opportunities they never had. It's something I carry with me every day, and it's one of the reasons I chose a career that allows me to give back to others in the same way they gave to me.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Elizabeth Smith: I hope that in a few years, I'm still living in Charleston, but maybe in a home of our own that we've worked hard to buy. I hope James and I have started a family, and that we're raising children who value education, kindness, and the importance of giving back to others. I also hope that my work continues to make a meaningful impact—whether it's through the nonprofit I'm with now or something else that allows me to support kids in underserved communities. I hope I'm still growing, still learning, and still finding joy in the little things, like our garden, our walks, and the quiet moments with my family. I hope I'm healthier, too—free from the back pain that's been a constant companion lately, and that I'm able to enjoy life with more energy and less worry. Most of all, I hope I'm still surrounded by the people I love—James, my parents, my sister, and the friends who've been there for me through it all. I think, in the end, that's what I want most: a life filled with love, purpose, and the sense that I've made the most of the opportunities I've been given.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Elizabeth Smith: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my partner James, my friends, or the community I live in. I think relationships are what give life meaning, and I'm so grateful for the people who have been there for me through every step of my journey. I also value growth, both personal and professional. I believe that life is about learning, adapting, and never stopping the pursuit of something better. I value the opportunities I've had, especially the ones that allowed me to break free from the limitations of my past and build a future for myself and for others. And I value gratitude—knowing that even in the hardest times, there's always something to be thankful for. Whether it's the support of my parents from afar, the love of James, or the small joys of our daily life, I try to hold on to that sense of gratitude because it's what keeps me grounded and hopeful for the future.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and work life are intertwined with my sense of purpose and well-being. Talking about our household income and how we manage our expenses reminded me of the hard work James and I both put in to build a life that feels secure, even if it's not perfect. It also made me think about how my job at the nonprofit isn't just about earning a paycheck—it's about contributing to something meaningful, something that helps others in ways that money alone can't measure. Reflecting on my workplace, my manager, and my coworkers reminded me of the importance of having a supportive environment where I can grow, learn, and feel valued. I'm grateful for the flexibility my job offers, which allows me to balance my work with my personal life, and for the relationships I've built with people who share my passion for making a difference. These conversations helped me appreciate how much I've grown—not just financially, but in terms of who I am and what I stand for.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It reminded me of how far I've come—from a young girl in Charleston, working part-time jobs to help my family, to the woman I am today, building a life with James, supporting my community, and nurturing my own growth. It made me realize how much my choices, both big and small, have shaped who I am. I think about the crossroads I faced when I chose the boarding school over staying in Charleston, and how that decision opened doors I never imagined. It also made me appreciate the people who supported me along the way—my mother, who believed in education, my friends who stood by me, and James, who has been my rock. This process has reminded me that life is not just about the challenges we face, but also about the connections we build, the lessons we learn, and the courage it takes to keep moving forward. I'm proud of the person I've become, and I'm excited for the future we're building together.
